channel.title: [C4D] City flood
channel.description:
I can't believe how bad this turned out. Originally I was just going to do a simple simulation testing some new ideas.
I modeled a city kinda, and gave it some shitty ass textures cause I didn't plan on having close ups. I faced the hardest part of visual effects, water. I thought since it'd be digital it wouldn't matter, but it is impossible to scale water. You can tell in old movies using miniatures (almost every movie) and water that the water isn't like an ocean. It's like a puddle. No big waves, just little jumps.
You can TOTALLY see that in this example lol. And the obvious jumpcut. Animation offset wasn't working so I had to record before the flood, and then record again after and match camera movement. Didn't work so well.
Anyways. Rip it.
http://blip.tv/file/1474705/

item.title: [C4D] City flood
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

[quote=“goatee, post:25, topic:244500”]Isn’t Blender better for this stuff? Look on youtube most water simulations are done with blender.

No. I just severely scaled it down and used fewer particles to keep simulation times low. Even though I have a beast machine for what I do, it’s still nothing compared to most others. Especially for simulation.

Realflow is specifically made FOR this stuff. Blender, isn’t. It might have the capability but it’s not better.

Like, how many major movies come out using blender particles?
And how many come out using realflow?

Read full topic

item.title: [C4D] City flood
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

keyframe it. You can do it multiple ways. I used to make a spline for it to follow and hook it to that because I didn’t know how to work everything. But there’s a much easier way.

The automatic keyframing buttons. Turn it on on the first frame. Move to the frame where you want the camera to be later on. Move the camera to that point. Move further along where you want it next time. Move/rotate camera. etc etc.

It makes a bezier curve for you that it follows and makes it seamless. But I always open the timeline and do some adjustments in the end.

Read full topic

item.title: [C4D] City flood
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Thank you guys
It’s really not up to my standards but still.

Tico what you’re trying to say is what I was explaining in my first post about nonscalable water. Even though this is a 3D model, it was built relatively small (3mx3m maybe) and importing into realflow makes it smaller as well. So you have a tiny scene filled by water. So this is how a 30cmx30cm (.1 scale in realflow) model would look filled with water. But with the camera being so close forced perspective makes it seem these buildings are life size. The water is not however. Those circles are just drops of water. If the city was bigger than real scale and turned out real scale in the simulation, those drops would be miniscule. But since the simulation used a tiny ass version of it, it’s like letting water loose in a lego city.

Water can’t be scaled. That’s the easy explanation.

Read full topic

item.title: [C4D] City flood
item.dc:creator: @Tico135 Tico
item.description:
@Tico135 wrote:

That’s a pretty good job if I do say so myself; it really doesn’t look that bad. The shadows and such were done rather well, and really you are looking at the water flowing into the city, not to the city itself, so it seems you decided correctly which area to work on more. The only thing I thought that could be improved on (this is constructive criticism ;)) is right before you zoom out to focus on the entire entire, I see some circle-like water figures which don’t make the water look like water. It’s difficult to explain, so if you don’t understand what I’m saying say so, and I’ll try to explain it a little better. This occurs at 0:06.

Read full topic
